Comment: Once more as White I choose to open with the King's Pawn.  This will be the last of these for awhile, since I have recently switched to the English Open in my games at the coffee shop due to there being less lines for me to memorise.  However, I still believe King's Pawn to be the most beneficial opening move for White, allowing you to avoid many types of slow manoeuvring games.
Black responds with the Sicilian, my favourite response to White's e4 opening.
Both natural development moves, allowing each player to stake a claim on the centre of the board.
Both natural development moves, allowing each player to stake a claim on the centre of the board.

White moves into the Rossolimo Variation of the Sicilian.  The aim of this is to allow for early castling while still building a strong central pawn structure, something White is often denied in the Sicilian.  When masters play, Bb5 is considered a move aimed at drawing the match but when Black is not prepared or unaware of the theory it can allow for White to gain a considerable advantage.
Considered to be "in book", I personally don't like it.  I think either e6 or d6 is the preferred move for Black here, attempting to gain an advantage in the centre.

Early castle followed by Black leaving the "book" moves for the  Rossolimo (which called for a6 here). e5 is well defended and gives Black a double threat on the unoccupied d4 square - I've always been told that control of the centre is essential for winning a chess match so Black is looking good.

Early castle followed by Black leaving the "book" moves for the  Rossolimo (which called for a6 here). e5 is well defended and gives Black a double threat on the unoccupied d4 square - I've always been told that control of the centre is essential for winning a chess match so Black is looking good.
White prepares to play d4.
Black threatens the undefended e4 pawn.
Black wins the exchange in material, creating doubled up passed pawns on the d-file in the process.  White's e4 pawn is still under threat and Black is already up in material.

White moves his e pawn to relative safety, threatening the Black Knight.
The Black Knight runs to immediate safety, but. . .
White continues the chase and threatens him again.
Black moves his Knight to defend the threatened Knight.  I preferred a6 here, threatening the exchange of Knight for Bishop.
Black threatens White's Bishop.
Black threatens White's Bishop.
Now White moves to take advantage, first by attacking the Black Queen.

Now White moves to take advantage, first by attacking the Black Queen.

And again, Black rushes to move to safety and commits a second mistake, the Hang mentioned in the title.  By moving here, Black hangs his pawn at e5, which White can take and check the Black King.  The furthest I went into the line was to move 23 (17.Qxe5+ Ne6 18.Bb4 Qc7 19.Qf5 Qf4 20.Qxf4 Nxf4 21.Nxf7 Be6 22.Bxe6 Nxe6 23.Nxh8 a5), which puts Black down by a Rook and two Pawns.  I think the move that should've been made is b6, which does sacrifice the Rook but keeps the King safe.
Pins Black's pawn at g7, forks Black's King and Pawn at g7 and isolates Black's pawn at d4.  White can almost taste victory.
White prevents the Black King from castling and keeps the pressure on Black.
White prevents the Black King from castling and keeps the pressure on Black.

And the final part of the title, Black moves into mate.  At the time I was unaware it was forced mate from here, but it certainly felt good.  During analysis, I discovered from here we're looking at 19.Rfe1 a5 20.Nxe6 fxe6 21.Bxe6 Qxe6 22.Qxg7 axb4 23.Rac1 Qxe1+ 24.Rxe1+ Be6 25.Rxe6+ Kd8 26.Qxd4+ Kc8 27.Re7 Kb8 28.Qe5+ Ka7 29.Qc5+ Kb8 30.Qc7+ Ka7 31.Qxb7#.  If I'm incorrect, please correct me but I'm fairly sure I'm right.  I think the best move was Qc7, with an eye for playing 18...Qc7 19.Qf5 Qf4 20.Qxf4 Nxf4 21.Nxf7 b5 22.Rfe1+ Kd7 23.Re7+
I still hadn't spotted a mate, so kept pressure on the Black King instead.
